qas.question: How do anthropologists typically like to divide up the world?

answers.text: relevant time periods and geographic regions

qas.question: How has human time on Earth been divided up?
Olduwan, Mousterian, and Levalloisian are all types of what?
Mapping cultures is central to both the sciences of anthropologists and who else?
What is a central part of the science of anthropology?
Who divides the world y theoretical emphasis?
Who likes to divide their projects into relevent time periods and geographic regions?

plausible_answers.text: cultural subdivisions according to tool types,

qas.question: What helps anthropologists understand major trends in human culture?
What is divided into relevant cultural traditions based on art?

context: Along with dividing up their project by theoretical emphasis, <b5_0><b6_0>anthropologists<b6_0/><b5_0/> typically divide the world up into <a0_0>relevant time periods and geographic regions<a0_0/>. <b8_0>Human time on Earth<b8_0/> is divided up into relevant <a1_0>cultural traditions based on material<a1_0/>, such as the Paleolithic and the Neolithic, of particular use in archaeology.[citation needed] Further <b7_0>cultural subdivisions according to <a2_0>tool<a2_0/> types,<b7_0/> such as Olduwan or Mousterian or Levalloisian help archaeologists and other anthropologists in understanding major trends in the human past.[citation needed] Anthropologists and <a3_0>geographers<a3_0/> share approaches to Culture regions as well, since mapping cultures is central to both sciences. By making comparisons across cultural traditions (time-based) and cultural regions (space-based), anthropologists have developed various kinds of <a4_0>comparative method<a4_0/>, a central part of their science.
